column4: rags nils@blackbox:~/installation$ sudo modprobe ip_conntrack_ftp

rags yup ... do I need more rules though? http://www.cyberciti.biz/tips/how-do-i-use-iptables-connection-tracking-feature.html seems to say that to use all teh FTP features in a NAT you need more than just teh one forwarding rule to get the related passive connections etc.
ab should be OK... does it give you an error or is the file empty? What does it do with one > ? else try | cat - >> /tmp/file
empty.
what does it output without the >> ?
franklin #ubuntu-es
same with single >.  i'll try cat - .
ab does it give you any output at all without piping at all?
no. worst case you end up with a command line and have to use that to reinstall a WM
just tried cat - .  nothing.  it does give output to stdout.  but redirecting to a file is not happening.
ab does it give the output to stdout when you add the pipe? if so, it's outputting to STDERR not STDOUT
ab else remove teh file, or check it has 660 privileges etc.
no output when piped through cat - .  the tcpdump manpage says -w - writes to stdout.  and i believe it does.  the perms on the file are good.  there is somehting else going on.
ab make the privs 777 or try sudo
ab or try it wirh tee (man tee)
tried both.  no change.
ab does echo test >> /tmp/file work then?
ab then try echo test | tee /tmp/file
tried | tee -a /tmp/file.  nothing.
the file is writable.

ab sorry, I can't help more than that... only other thing I can think of is that it's buffered before flushing to the file or something if you see output without the pipe and not with and nothing in the file, but even then after a while something should be in the file
yep.  i thougt about buffering but the -l switch is supposed to address that.  i think it's maybe the lack of an EOF.  the stdout never gets closed.
